Posted: October 8, 2016
												First off, forget the play time, that's not accurate.Enslaved was a game that first caught my attention years ago when I saw the preview in a GameInformer magazine. It was a time when the first person shooter was kind of the gaming industry, and the different gameplay caught my attention as well as the highly stylized visuals that were striking and bright in an era of browns and grays. Unfortunately at that time I didn't have a PS3 or 360 to pick the game up, so my memory fell to the way side.Cut to 5 years later when I have a PC that can actually do some gaming and I notice that Enslaved is now on Steam, and for cheap, too! I picked it up on a Christmas sale (or maybe a Humble Bundle) and let it sit for many months; finally, I mention to a friend that I had bought it and he looks at me and and says "You need to play that game, it's fantastic." This friend happened to be my professor in Game Design (which I went to school for), and I knew if he was saying something, then it needed to jump to the top of my priorities list.The first thing I noticed about the game other than the visual style was the controls. They felt a bit clunky and strange for keyboard controls and it was immediately obvious that this was a pretty straightforward port from the console version, as opposed to a redefined experience with a different control scheme. At first, some of the button placements for various moves felt awkward, but as I made my way through the first tutorial level, I began to get the flow of everything, and the seemingly strange buttons started to make sense. Don't get me wrong, I would definitely recommend playing this on a controller, but if you must use a mouse and keyboard, it grows on you.After tackling the controls and coming out on top, I finally manage to let myself become engrossed in the story and atmosphere of it all, and that's where this game really shines. The story itself is fairly straightforward, but not boring. It's interesting, and when it is coupled with the fantastic world around it, then it begins to flow well. This is a different post-apocalypse, a brighter one. One that is less grit, and more grease. Everything shines, and when you're not in a lush city being retaken by nature, you're in a junkyard fortress, or some other fantastic environment. The thing is, even when the game gets deep and shadowy, it never truly gets visually dark, a post-apocylptic aesthetic that is rarely seen nowadays. The closest I can really get is somethinng like The Last of Us with less smog and spores, and fresh air instead.As great as the environment is though, it's the characters that really make this game. Trip, Monkey, and eventually Pigsy are fantastic characters that grow over the course of their adventure, and have ended up becoming some of my favorite game characters of all time. It's not so much their adventure that drives this game, but their development as people during it. And possibly the most important part to making these characters come alive are thier voice actors. Andy Serkis as Monkey, Lindsey Shaw as Trip, and Richard Ridings as Pigsy give these characters life through their dialogue in only the way a talented voice actor can. All three are fantastic, but I believe that Serkis is easily the standout of the group, and his portrayal of Monkey is absolutely wondrous.All in all, this game is a fantastic journey, and one I believe that any gamer who appreciates games as an art should partake in. It has impressed me in a way very few games have managed, and I feel that I've learned much as a gamer, developer, and writer from it.TL;DR - Play it, iz real good.

Posted: February 7, 2016
 An Unexpected, if Mixed Journey to the West(Full disclosure: I bought this game on impulse during a sale and had it sitting in my library for almost two years before I played it)Inspired by one of the most well-known of the four great classics of Chinese literature, Journey to the West, Odyssey to the West plays fast and loose with much of its source material in interesting ways. As someone who isn't particularly interested in the source material, I wasn't terribly bothered by its deviations, though history geeks will have a field day ripping it a new one.Odyssey to the West's shining achievement is its story and the relationship between Trip and Monkey. Trip herself is a gold mine of interesting character interpretations: is she just a teenager using whatever tools she can to survive in a world gone mad, even if it involves enslaving a man? Or does she seriously lack empathy and is willing to break promises for the sake of revenge? .Monkey's no slouch either, being much more than just a muscular, snarking, angry anti-hero. The way they play off each other is fantastic, and with the exception of one scene near the end of the game, I was completely enthralled by how their relationship progressed. The authenticity of Monkey and Trip's relationship brings to mind the best partnerships in gaming, such as Joel and Ellie from The Last of Us, or Link and Midna from Twilight Princess. Unfortunately, there are no other "real" characters besides these two, which makes the game feel empty. The two named characters that are introduced besides them , Pigsy and Pyramid,  fall flat due to the former's irritating mannerisms (with few redeeming moments, though they are meaningful) and the latter's lack of screentime. The war that tore the planet is barely talked about, reducing much of its significance since there's effectively zero information about the world before it was destroyed, or what destroyed it. The lack of audio logs, codexes, or other information-giving collectibles would have alleviated this, but the only collectibles are those used for upgrades, and masks, which are effectively meaningless until the end of the game.Though the game suffers from some loading glitches and framerate drops, the game is still gorgeous, with a richly detailed post-apocalyptic world that reminds me of, yet again, The Last of Us. Destroyed mechanical titans lay in scattered heaps on overgrown, damp city streets, and giant junkyards made of cobbled-together mechanical parts offer safe passage over dangerously oily water. The world is full of color and light. The animation work is excellent. While not yet crossing the uncanny valley, facial movements are accurate and impressive. Monkey's movements in particular are a sight to behold, as he dodges, clambers up ledges, and even holds himself in an accurately simian manner.The music is surprisingly good, reminding me a bit of the Metroid Prime games in a good way, and the voice acting is impressive and nuanced.Unfortunately, the gameplay is more of a mixed bag. While combat is satisfying, it quickly grows repetitive due to the very limited pools of moves available and the lack of enemy variety, since all enemies are just robots that fall into one of five categories and feature various states of rust or disuse. The ability to exploit flaws in your enemies' design is interestng, on the other hand (for example, ripping open a decayed power cell on a scout to turn him into a walking bomb), opening up opportunities to turn the tide in unexpected ways.Boss fights are a letdown. While a few early ones are interesting, they gradually drop in quality due to overly large health bars, poorly-scripted phase changes, or the recycling of previous bosses.Upgrading Monkey requires currency that can be found around the world or gathered from enemies, and while most don't drastically change your playstyle and are of varying usefullness, filling out Monkey's skill trees is still fun, if irritating due to how hard it is to find tech orbs after you've cleared a level.The few vehicles sections handle well and don't overstay their welcome. Monkey has a  Cloud (actually a disk, but you know what they were going for)  that he busts out for some bosses or watery areas, and it's a blast to rocket around on it.Traversal feels remarkably similar to Infamous in all the best ways. Monkey can grapple, climb, jump, or swing from impressively high or complicated structures, and the movement itself can almost become an engaging sort of puzzle.Speaking of puzzles, some of the environment-based ones are quite entertaining, though not on the level of a dedicated puzzle game. An encounter in a dilapidated opera house that requires you to manipulte props, scaffolding, and lighting is particularly interesting.Unfortunately, the camera is your constant enemy, rapidly changing orientation when you round a corner or failing to indicate where to go next when grappling around. In combat, it can often fail to properly display where enemies are, and its sluggish movement makes the (thankfully rare) shooting sections incredibly frustrating.While I won't detail specifics, the final level tries too hard to wrap up loose ends and feels anticlimactic in comparison to previous stages. The ending in particular is sudden and confusing, attempting to introduce elements minutes before the credits roll.ENSLAVED: Odyssey to the West is not a bad game. The story, characters (all two of them), sound and visuals are almost universally excellent, and some of the combat, puzzles and exploration can be fun. However, the overall lack of variety or depth in the combat, letdowns in terms of the story, and some truly terrible camera angles, shooting sections, and boss fights keep this back from achieving true greatness in all respects.Also, seriously, Trip, please put more clothes on. Pros: Trip and Monkey's relationship is the highlight of the game Excellent music and voice acting Colorful, interesting world design and characters Upgrade system is satisfying Puzzles and movement are engaging Vehicle sections don't take too long Cons: Repetitive, shallow combat The god-damn camera No interesting characters besides Trip and Monkey, or really any, for that matter Visual bugs and framerate drops The ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ camera Shooting sections are frustrating because of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ camera Boss fights are lackluster Ending leaves much to be desired The GODAMN CAMERA Seriously, Trip, please put something else on. No, not the "Sexy Robot Trip" outfit, that's worse.

Posted: July 14, 2015
												Surprisingly entertaining title, especially if you get it during a sale. Simple, fast paced, gripping, funny characters.However, it suffers from the controls which are not so well ported to PC, and the graphics that are somewhat sub-par for 2015. But despite those niggles and some issues with configuring the graphics settings in the .ini file, it's still a game you might want to try if you get it on sale.Can't really recommend it, though. The PC port feels as if done by a drunken intern hating his job. Plenty of bugs, such as when you're chased by a robo dog and supposed to run through a pipe through which the (giant) dog can't follow... but it simply does? Also, single-Checkpoint games are a legacy idiocy from console games 20 years ago. Today, it's just nonsense - and for games that are such buggy ports that the single save is easily broken, lost, or destroyed... It basically means - don't waste your time, you may have to redo the whole game at any point in time. Just lost all stuff I bought with tech orbs. Simply gone after restarting the game. No older save available.Crap.

Posted: July 17, 2015
												Just completed this game for the second time and it is still an incredible experience. Technically, the gameplay is fantastic. The platforming is amongst the best I've ever played (and I was playing on keyboard and mouse, which has recieved mixed reviews from other reviewers). Very fluid controls with a satisfying upgradability feature. The enemies are very well done and the challenge does ramp up towards the end (though it's a very easy playthrough on Normal -- next time I'll definitely play it on Hard mode because Normal doesn't provide any challenge whatsoever in my experience). But what you should play this game for is the story. It's very rare I've found a game that is so expansive (for a linear game, at any rate). The environments are varied and the game never gets stale from the opening chapter to the very end. Some deadly boss battles too, which is a great plus and keeps it engaging. But, the story is just breathtaking. There are few games that've left me speechless and fewer still that've left me thinking about whether or not I did the right thing at the end. This is definitely one of them. It's a game that leaves you thinking.Highly recommended for all fans of platforming, action, and above all story-driven games. 10/10

Posted: August 30, 2015
												ENSLAVED presents us with quite a conundrum.  It entertains us very well.  The characters, environments, animation and voice acting are excellent.  The plot is sparse and cliche, but it's no worse than many movie plots.  But that's the conundrum: it isn't really a game.  It's more of an interactive movie.  You move the thumbstick and hit button A over and over again to make the movie continue, but at no point is there any decision to make.  The only part that is a game is the combat, but this is mostly so simple that it would never stand up as its own game without the rest of the movie-parts.I'm not sure how I feel about this new form of entertainment.  Yes it's good while you're experiencing the content, but the development cost must have been equivalent to a blockbuster movie.  I'm not sure if that is worthwhile given it has no replayability.  There are many games with low budgets and little content that manage to provides hundreds of hours of entertainment by virtue of the gameplay.  For games, fun is almost like an emergent property, not directly proportional to how much effort the developers took.  I wonder if this would have been as good or better as a movie or mini-series.

Posted: October 28, 2016
												My opinion of this game has varied throughout, and I'll do my best to explain how that's gone.After the first chapter (or thereabouts), I was pretty sure that I was playing a generic action game, starring Generic Angry White Man and Irritating 'Can't Do Anything Myself' Girl. The story seemed to be littered with Deus Ex Machina after Deus Ex Machina, and I was not expecting much more than a mindless fight-the-robots romp. But during the game, this completely changed - I'm not sure whether the game got better or if I suddenly 'got' something I hadn't noticed before, but I started to really enjoy it.The story got a lot stronger as it went on, and the character development is perfectly paced. As I learnt more about the characters, I became more fond of them, and by the last couple of chapters, I was completely invested in them. The actors did a fine job with the voice work, and even though there are only three characters in the entire game, it doesn't suffer for it in the least. The story itself was excellent, with humour balancing the more emotional parts nicely. My only complaint is that the epilogue felt a little bit rushed as an end to the story, but it did tie things up nicely.Combat in the game is a great mix of hand-to-hand and shooting with Monkey's staff, and the flow between each style is really good. While the hand-to-hand reminds me a little of Remember Me, it's nowhere near as complex, and it can often be the best option to button mash until you defeat the enemies. The one thing that I really didn't like was the parkour-style elements. Sure, it looked nice, and hopping between hand-holds, bars and other things was fluid, but I would have liked a bit more freedom. There seems to always be one way, and one way only, to reach where you are going, and most of the time you are railroaded into that way by being completely unable to even try and jump anywhere else.I'm honestly surprised that I hadn't really heard of this game before I played it - it's got some big names behind it, and it's so well-made. Definitely worth playing.

Posted: July 10, 2016
												(writing this about halfway through the game, I think. Completed through chapter 7.)There's a few glitches, but most of them aren't gamebreaking. I've had to restart a checkpoint a few times.The sparsity of checkpoints is actually my main complaint. When hunting for all of the tech orbs, sometimes I have to go back several minutes to try a segment again. I believe the game saves what you've picked up when you restart such a checkpoint, but it's not consistent for me - I kept having to pick up the same orb behind me during the final shootout in chapter 7.Auto-targeting is another problem. I can't seem to keep focused on one enemy to finish them off. Luckily, a stun lasts for a set period of time and isn't broken when I use a regular attack, but it's aggravating in some of those frantic multi fights.Graphics: eh. I played a lot of DmC, so the colors/aesthetics feel kinda samey. If you *haven't* played DmC, it's lush, and beautiful. Sometimes it's too bright and colorful for me to find the next platforming segment. Trip's pants make no sense, but whatever.Also: not very good with alt-tabbing. There's no windows/no border option in the graphics, so it's crashed a few times. Beware!The story is great so far. I think I've really become a fan of how Ninja Theory does their character relationships. Even though Monkey is the controlled character, is more experienced, and does all of the fighting, Trip is treated as an equal.I picked this up because of a passing interest in Journey to the West, and the story is roughly paralleling what I know about the original plot, but in futurepunk ways. It's neat to guess what's coming next!The platforming works. Wonky platforming controls aren't too bad, because the game will only let you jump to valid locations. So that's nice.This feels like it's mostly detailing my complaints, but I'm always eager to continue to the next chapter, to see what happens next.

												Enslaved is without a doubt one of rare and often overlooked gems from that failed to get the proper recognition it sorely deserves. Posted: June 18, 2015
												I'll be honest. I am only a little way into chapter two, not very far along at all. Yet the game definately has me intrigued. It is aa dynamic combination of storytelling and platform style gaming with plenty of jumping, climbing and navigating through difficut terrain, and of course, combat. You play primarily as Monkey (a character is aptly named due to his nimbleness in how he is able to jump and climb) but also occassioanlly direct Trip. There is plenty of action in this game but with some nice cutscenes here to make it interesting for a player like myself, whose primary intrest in gaming is actually RPGs. I'm not a 'hardcore game' who makes evaluations of combat sstyles and such, so I won't go into that, other than to say that for me at least, the combat is difficult enough to be enjoyable, without being overwhelming.  My only complaints are that the game autosaves with no player save options. You have to go along until you hit a save point, or you will loose your progress. Also, there is no pause button (that I have discovered yet anyway) so if the dorbell  or phone rings in the middle of a sequence, you have to either not answer, or let the game do what it will, and hope your last save point was not too far back (this actually happened to me during my first play through in th emiddle of a demanding sequence. I had to bite the bullet and let Monkey die to go answer the door...) So far though, I am REALLY enjoying this game and it is a nice break/distraction from WoW.

Posted: June 17, 2015
												Interesting game and story concept, but falls short with cheap game mechanics.I've played very few games that are as predictable as this, game-play wise. You can literally call out what's going to happen next based on what your character can or can't do, or the task you've been assigned. What baffles me the most about this game is you play as this extremely strong and destructive character, and yet (probably because of the plot line) you take an alternate route and get yourself into a mess because you can't jump up a ledge or crawl under something...no reasons why really...you just can't. (Oh and if you can't figure out where to jump, just spin the left stick and mash "A", since you can't misstep (and die) he'll only go where he's allowed to.)The female protagonist/partner? Nah she's OK, she has her own private walkway to take unlike you. It's not like they'd give her a weapon or something right? Hey hurry up you slacker, she's waiting for you to catch up. No, stop playing with the deadly robots. It upsets me that her character was so useless in the entire game, aside from needing an extra pair of hands or comic relief.But the story does save it, and it's a unique one as far as I'm concerned. The worlds are also beautiful given what they had to work with (thanks consoles, for your limitations). The characters actually speak and hold conversations both in and out of cut-scenes.Pick this up on sale.

Posted: June 30, 2015
												It's not awful, but its many issues prevent it from being excellent. Overall ~7/10.-The combat is dull, repetitive, and a lot of button mashing (but so are the majority of action games)-The platforming is mindless and nearly impossible to mess up, aside from a few areas toward the end-Music and sounds are alright, but nothing to write home about (I have no idea why people tagged this as having a "great soundtrack" when it was mostly forgettable background music)-To call them puzzles would be insulting to actual puzzles (although to be fair most actions games nowadays do this too), but they were fast enough that they felt more like elements of the platforming rather than contrived timewasters-Fairly short at ~10-13 hours (length felt about right to me, YMMV) -If you're a completionist and you miss any of the collectibles/achievements you'll have to replay the entire chapter (no manual saving, points of no return occur every ~5-10 minutes)-The colors and art really brought things to life, and are some of the game's stronger points-Voice acting was excellent-Repetitive level design with no real changes to mechanics (gaining the ability to shoot plasma out of your staff (no innuendo) hardly qualifies)-Despite its predictability and lack of content the story was alright...until the last chapter. They decided to royally♥♥♥♥♥♥the bed there for god knows what reason; enough of a ♥♥♥♥-up to consider giving it a thumbs down. Without spoiling anything, the story's background became increasingly shaky and farfetched in the last third or so (but tolerable), and had a horrible, unsatisfying "conclusion" that made no sense in the story's setting. The presumed attempt to be dramatic and thought-provoking resembled an adolescent's fan fiction, or anything from M. Night Shyamalan. It didn't really give a proper conclusion, but left some room for a sequel, and wound up in a purgatory where it neither fully finished the story nor made a continuation necessary.-Main character is the hellspawn of Superman and a gorilla, so his inhuman physical abilities can frequently give the false appeareance of Trip being a damsel in distress-This type of game feels a lot like games made 10-15 years ago, and it would have been right at home amongst them. However, following an (outdated) cookie cutter action game design is not going to make you stand out.It didn't really do anything unique, and with gameplay/story elements ranging from mediocre to slightly above average, it's hard to say that this game is underappreciated. Collecting magical orbs, jumping on platforms, and pressing x like a monkey whenever you're in combat just isn't that stimulating, or maybe I'm just too old. Despite everything wrong with it, I can't articulate why I still enjoyed it. It had a nebulous quality that made it fun to play and want to see through to the end; might have been my nostalgia for older action games. It wasn't bad, and I don't regret playing it, but if you're looking for something amazing, you can do better.

Posted: December 23, 2016
												PRO:+ Great graphics+ Great main characters + Good fight mechanics+ Good enough plotCONS:- When 3rd character enters, kills the chemestry of main characters- Camera- Parkour controls sometimes are messy- You need Trip for heal and level up, but she is not with you most of the final act- Abrupt lame endingFull review:Great game with action and good characters. Protecting Trip even though she "enslaved" you doesn't seem like a shore and she is actually more useful and resourceful than you would think (in the late game when she is not with you, you start to miss her), not to mention the interaction between the characters is pretty cute - until a pig enters the picture. Anyway, reminds of the high-quality Sony Square-Enix games.On the gameplay front, a not-so-good port. You will spend A LOT of time fighting the camera (which will sometimes stick to some very strange angles that make moving hard), and the controls in some parts get confusing on the parkour parts because of the camera changing angles and all of the sudden "UP" (W) will make you jump back because you had to know (right?) that this time, to go up you need "UP+LEFT" (A+W). But that is mostly on the "parkour" moves (think Tomb Raider).I will, however, say two things about the plot (no spoilers): When the "Pigsy" character shows up, the story goes downhill fast, he is literally a third-wheel. And the ending ... abrupt and leave you hanging.Other issues: There is a bug on the shadows that require some .ini tweaking, but nothing serious. And the menus are REALLY weird and unresponsive sometimes (adding upgrades sometimes is a pain. Anyway, as mentioned, port issues), but the game itself is really great.8/10 - if the camera was better and there were no pig, would be a 10/10

Posted: December 6, 2016
												Enslaved has defenitely made it into my top favorite games! Its story is touching, the charcters lovable (well, maybe not Pigsy) and the fighting is fun. There are so much more different facial expressions than I've ever seen in a game before. You always know how the characters are feeling.The small bossfights are fun, and really, who doesnt want to fly around on a mechanical cloud and do cool stunts? I disliked some things, like the Machine Gun defense games, where you just have to stay on one point an shoot everything, but luckily, there are not too many of those. I also disliked Pigsy, but thats maybe just me.So whoever wants to play a game with a great story, and amazing scenery, I recommend this to you!

Posted: November 30, 2016
												This is a lot more fun than some people gave it. The combat is easy to get a hang of but it delivers a challenge in some situations depending on difficulty.. On Normal I had enough of a challange to be entertained. Story is pretty interesting, I like games that kinda just drop you in the middle of a timeline and you work out what happened before you ended up there while you progress and figure out whats going to happen next so story telling is done well. Also the environments are very intriguing.. It's probably the hipster to other post cyber apocalypse games... Although I'm sure there are other games with similar concepts that outdate this one. Posted: December 2, 2016
												So I bought this game at least two years ago. I had trouble getting to it with other games I felt I would have more fun playing. I felt ashamed it took me this long to play this game. A fantastic story mixed with lovable characters. The combat wasn't all that challenging but I played it more for the story and characters. I was never bored of the combat but it just wasn't hard. The best part is that I could quit or pause whenever I wanted to and get right back into later on. There isn't that many games that although that nowadays. At one time I took a hiatus of at least a week or two from it. I came back and was able to pick right up where I left off. The story was memorable enough so that I didn't forget and the mechanics are easy enough to pick up right away. I can't praise this game enough for everything it does right, highly recommend it!

Posted: November 14, 2014

Exciting story and gameplay, great to look at, no wonky controls, decent upgrade system, combat is fun, and riding the cloud is fantastically enjoyable. The music brilliantly done, too.Seems it could use a patch - there are a few threads floating around about good rigs having bouts of freezing, often during cutscenes. Is it annoying? Yes. Does it detract from the gameplay? Maybe. Should it stop you from buying this game? Not on your life.

Posted: November 27, 2016
												As the tag suggested, this game is indeed a post-apocalyptic game. Unlikes the Fallouts, the setting suggests something much like a Borderlands and Darksider-like apocalypse. What, I presumed, a player would really like about this game is that the gameplay/combat. Unlike some of the game I played before like Kingdom of Amalur or Elder Scroll Skyrim, this game promotes other way of approaching combar. Combat aside, let's move onto the characters. In the main game, you as a Monkey, somewhat like  in the Chinese myth - Journey to the West, you are accompanied by a lady named Trip. However, this game has flaws, flaws like glitch n bugs are understandable, but flaws like the game is devoid of player-character interaction is what really bugs me. I'm not going to talk about the story ,in the end, it is still up to you as a fellow gamer to judge it. This is really an underated game, thus I'm willing to nominate the unnoticed gem in the 'I THOUGHT THIS GAME WAS COOL BEFORE IT WON AN AWARD' award. Yes, double award. Posted: October 22, 2016
 Great game, lots of funAfter having read tons of reviews here on Steam I decided to give it a go and got it during one of the innumerable crazy-for-whatever-reason-on-steam-sales. Then it got stuck on my library for ages until I found the time to actually play it (which was the past week during autumn vacation) - and I loved almost every part of it. I'm not a fan of console ports and usually avoid them. This game was clearly designed with controllers in mind and when you fire it up, you get a nice welcome message remembering you "not to shut down the console, because this game saves automatically". PC gamer pride aside and some initial struggle playing with mouse & keyb I quickly fell in love with it. It's basically a sci-fi hack'n'slay with a nice plot and some AC badass climbing (with pre-fixed anchor points you can't miss mind you) in a Mad Max'isch environment. The characters are likeable though I lack the background information about the universe, the past of it, how everyone got where they are and who they are basically. Think of entering LOTR on the last chapter, where you figure the Ring is evil, you understand who's good and bad and you know it has to be destroyed - you just don't know how everyone got there.Pro's The fights are fun though there aren't real combos You have a series of finishing moves and one allows you to take a mech as shield or throw him The environments change, you can take cover and figure out how to approach the next fight Likable characters, though the girl is utterly vulnerable Nice plot - probably part of a larger story Extra: The pigsy plot line will add an extra story (though tiny) and different moves (grapple hook) with extra gadgets such as EMP's, friendly mechs, mines and decoy bombs once you have finished the main story. Pigsy, instead of Monkey, uses a sniper rifle and no hand-to-hand combat at all - so it's a different playCon's Nice plot - but lacks some sophisticated background story (I would have liked to understand more Camera behaviour had me almost puke sometimes At some spots it wasn't all clear how to proceed in the otherwise completely linear levelsI would recommend the game at any time. Despite some minor flaws it was just plain fun and diverse and never really felt repetitive. Though from a graphical perspective it doesn't live up to today's standards, it's an utter delight in colors and fireworks.

Posted: February 18
												I'm gonna go with a YEAH - OH HELL YEAH - on this one.As a guy who was spoon-fed the old-school cartoon version of The Monkey King as a child, (the one that was too ugly to be called anime,) I was somewhat skeptical on this reboot. And, though I will grant that the whole post-apocalypse-robots-wasteland-deal took a while to grow on me, I must confess, in the end: The story, (it took forever after the opening Action Sequence too get REALLY interesting,) quite simply DRAGS you into it, (kicking and screaming if it has to,) and if you have ANY knowledge of the original story I mentioned earlier, you can't help but contemplate the complexity of the concept, once you've finished the game. (noooooo WAKE UP... Not Even One spoiler! - Once you've finished the game y'all might even get that joke.)Right, so... The game itself - (I'll leave the story with you for evaluation.) The controls are actually so easy you have to make an effort to get it wrong, (granted it'll take you a while to learn to trust that fact.) Other games could learn something from these Devs. I'm not saying this platform of control or key configuration is the best ever, cause it's not. It's just that the controls are SO responsive that you actually have to be CAREFUL not to jump the gun. (You'll understand soon enough. Half of the game IS a 3D-Platformer, after all...)The Graphics are utterly beautiful, spectacular and fantastic. (Granted, there are a few "gaps," where you go WTF because the beauty goes right out the window. But it's not that big a deal. The Game never really loses touch with it's background scene, so it works even without the sparkles on it.)The extras are... - extra. I don't really know how else to put it. You don't really need it. You don't really need to go through the game again with a new "mod" turned on, but if you wanna replay, and re-experience the stunning story with a completely "weird" or "ridiculous" outfit or other mods, you can. I personally didn't. (But then, I spent a good long week, after completing the game, reasoning out all the story-lines shout-outs to the Original Story; the philosophy; the multitude of morals implied in the game; and how absurdly many White Rabbits there are sprinkled around the entire storyline.)Combat System: Oh for the love of pete... - I know I said the controls are fabulous, (cause they are, repsonse-wise) but the combat/shooting system is REALLY flawed. Multi-target tracking is TOO DAMNED SLOW. (You'll get why later on in the game, when multiple enemies begin to become a stable fixture.)Puzzles - Well, they're not Mensa-Crackers but they WILL annoy you, if nothing else, because they take time to complete. - (You WILL be happy once you're finished with one, and curse the Devs whenever you find the next one...) But that's the way with puzzles in a 3D platform game, isn't it?Funfactor... - Meh...! It's fun the first time. But It's kind of an adrenaline-based thing. Run over here. Move this. Up, down, right, bla bla bla. Kill this, hack that, hurry, move this way - OOPS blocked, find another way. All the while, usually with a "hurry or your companion will die!" kind of thing hanging over you. It works, once. I found it hard to engage properly during the second playthrough, but I'm thinking it was just too soon. I've since left the game on the shelf a while to age a bit. I'm thinking when I dust it off again and play it once more, it'll be fun again.So Overall?Pros 7/10 - Good Game; Great Story;  Interesting Characters (they actually grow with the story! thumbs up for the writers!)  ; Great Graphics, SOOOO MUCH Better Than Average Controls, everythings explained, everythings understandable and generally doable, (just mind your timing,) ; the multiphasing platforming (and that's as far as I'll go towards spoilers,) works very well, even if it's a little confusing at first; Great, Scenic, Rich 3D Environments for a Platformer! - I DO hope that other Devs are taking notes. Depth Matters!Cons 3/10 - The Combat/Shooting System (see above) is without a doubt the most frustrating problem in the entire game. I died more times during "that" phase than I did in the rest of the entire game; Replayabillity; I love your game, Devs and I love your effort, but it's a little heavy to pick up a second time in short order, when you know the score and how it all plays out - (F-Y-I, a couple of mods won't change that. I WILL play again, but it won't be because of the mods.) ; Finally - Not enough FUN-Factor. The game, while certainly a great re-boot of the Monkey King lore, a great take on the 3D-multi-Platformer, a gorgeous piece of art, graphics-wise - it's all good, really - but there's a lack of good clean fun. (Oh I DID laugh quite a bit during the development of the story and the characters, but it was all soooo serious. I get it, I do, The Monkey King was big on High Drama. But it was funny too. So if you're gonna revamp it, why not do the funny as well? I'm not asking for Crash Bandicoot fall on your bum Fun, or witty one-two-or-three-liners. Just give us a reason to like PLAYING the game, besides getting it out the way so we can get to the next cut-scene?)So... - Good game. Very Pretty. Great Story. Fun, but not tons of it. I'd reccomend it to Story-Lovers, whether they know or like The Monkey King saga, or not. Oh yeah, and just so you know, (I like this, but I'm guessing some people don't,) from a gamer's point of view, this game is LOOOOOOOONG! So bring patience, lean back, and enjoy.

Posted: January 14
												I didn't expect to like this game as much as I did. Obviously I expected to like it, or I wouldn't have bought it, but while I expected "okay", I got "pretty great actually".I've completed the main story at time of writing, but there are still extra things to do so I'll still be playing for a few more days. Maybe even a second run to complete achievements. The main story is about twenty hours long (on hard) if you don't make too many mistakes, and it's pretty damn linear."Linear" never used to be my thing, but Enslaved does it well. It has a story to tell and it tells it, and in my opinion the cutscenes, voice acting, and general characterisation are great. They really brought the game up from "worth playing" to "you should play this". Be warned, though, if you're looking for a faithful retelling of Monkey's Journey to the West, you will be sorely disappointed. This is the definition of loose adaptation. If you know the original story, you will see clever little references, but if you don't this is not the way to learn it. This is, in fact, a completely original story that happens to contain elements from Journey to the West.I recommend playing with a controller. I don't often say this, because in 90% of cases KB+M is always going to be better, but this is definitely one of those remaining 10%. Platforming and combat are incredibly awkward, but not downright impossible, without a joystick of some kind.And, yes, the other reviews are right. This is a bad port. Fortunately, most of the major issues can be fixed by tweaking inis, and there are plenty of guides right here on steam on how to do that.Much more fun than expected. Marginally more feels than expected.EDIT: Pigsy's Perfect 10 is surprisingly challenging, and I love his "crouch".

Posted: February 13
												Short review: Graphics 4.5/5 stunning and incredible and thats just on medium settingsGamePlay 4.5/5  tight-ish controls if you've played any of the batman arkham series you will get to grips with it fastStory 4/5 Post apocolyptic retelling of the classice story journey to the west. A couple of meh moments with the story but overall amazing4/5 overallindepth reviewGraphics. 4.5/5 Incredible graphics while i do have a gaming pc its not the most powerfull and didnt want to take my chances playing on high graphics but even on medium the game looks outstanding, stunning scenery in the newyork level looks breathtaking in both beauty and shock. amazing job with monkey to look like the monkey king ( as he should) but also at times can look like an actual monkey with a slightly sloped posture and bare feet and slight jutting of the lower jaw.  Motion capture and voice for monkey being done by andy serkis ( gollum and ceasar)  so you know you're in for a treat there but i honestly couldnt tell it was him i was getting the vibe of a differnt actor with how he looks  a more Sean Pertwee ( lestrad in elementary) and another vide with the voice acting cant quite place my finger on it.Story 4/5 Post apocalyptic retelling of the chinese classice journy to the west while ive not read or seen the original i certainly will be after this. While i was already familiar with the persona of the monkey king from other media i quickly picked up on who monkey was meant to be right around the time he got his staff ( big give away to be honest). The story is great a couple of moments that honestly seems meh in my opinion but overall has been keeping my interest im only up to chapter 11 but im loving every bit of it and looking forward to delving deeper in to this post apocalyptic worldGameplay 4.5/5 Now this is what ive got the most to talk about. Like i said in the short review if you have played any of the batman arkham series you will quickly get to grips with the controls as the movement and combat system work very similar to them including some of the cons such as if you get caught on the very edge of a corner/barricade it can be awkward moving around it.The free running is amazing While it can feel slightly unresponsive sometimes but i chalk this up to me trying to rush it too fast. it is very fluid and incredibly fun, I got a slight simpler version of assasins creed feel going at the free running climbing moments the slight glow to the objects you can climb make it a lot easier to see them in the dense enviroment but not so much as to be glareingly obviouse.The combat. Oh boy now i can imagine a lot of people who have a problem with this game might be with the combat as you can very easily get overwhelmed by the mechs youfight and have your health dropped very quickly as well as it feel like you have to struggle with every fight. and honestly while for most other games this could be a problem i found it worked very well for Enslaved due to the story and what you are fighting every fight feels like you are facing something that can easily kill you but not to a dark souls point just enough to give you the feel of having to pay attention to what you're doing or at least be aware as to where all the mechs are. That being said once you upgrade your stun attack fights quickly become much easier to deal with. But the combat always felt very satifying to do, I would of liked to see more combos and special moves you could unlock/upgrade to spice things up a little more. over all this game is a very solid 4/5  and while i got this from the recent bandai namco humble bundle now that ive paid it i would gladly say £15 is a fair price for such a well made game

Posted: February 9
												This is one of those flawed games that you can play and wonder about how a few little things could have made it better. Controls aren't good, it's very picky about the place where you can jump from, and when you are climbing you must point the stick in the direction of the next spot but it isn't always where it seems to be onscreen (also keyboard configuration is atrocious and onscreen all cues are displayed showing gamepad buttons). The story is not great either, but the dialogs and face expressions are good (also short, no exposition) and convey what the characters are feeling (largely unused in video games: telling with facial expressions).The combat becomes tedious and some aspects of it exist but are almost useless unless you upgraded them, like the shield, for instance. It is weak, too weak when you start, but if you upgraded a couple times it becomes useful. So you must pick if you want to hit harder or to be harder to kill, because in one playthrough you won't be able to get all the upgrades. But if you play the chapters again you play with all your upgrades from the previous playthrough, so you start overpowered even if you move from Medium to Hard difficulty.It is about 12 hours long and you have the premium version you can also play Pigsy Perfect 10 (check the Extras menu), it is more focused on platforming and gadgets than in melee combat and gives you another 3 hours of gameplay. It's also a stand alone story, not related with the main game's.Nowadays, with all the sales, you can buy it for cheap, and if you have time to spare it'll give you a decent time.

Posted: February 9
												This is one of those flawed games that you can play and wonder about how a few little things could have made it better. Controls aren't good, it's very picky about the place where you can jump from, and when you are climbing you must point the stick in the direction of the next spot but it isn't always where it seems to be onscreen (also keyboard configuration is atrocious and onscreen all cues are displayed showing gamepad buttons). The story is not great either, but the dialogs and face expressions are good (also short, no exposition) and convey what the characters are feeling (largely unused in video games: telling with facial expressions).The combat becomes tedious and some aspects of it exist but are almost useless unless you upgraded them, like the shield, for instance. It is weak, too weak when you start, but if you upgraded a couple times it becomes useful. So you must pick if you want to hit harder or to be harder to kill, because in one playthrough you won't be able to get all the upgrades. But if you play the chapters again you play with all your upgrades from the previous playthrough, so you start overpowered even if you move from Medium to Hard difficulty.It is about 12 hours long and you have the premium version you can also play Pigsy Perfect 10 (check the Extras menu), it is more focused on platforming and gadgets than in melee combat and gives you another 3 hours of gameplay. It's also a stand alone story, not related with the main game's.Nowadays, with all the sales, you can buy it for cheap, and if you have time to spare it'll give you a decent time.

Posted: February 9
												So, my feelings on this game are mostly positive but there are some pretty big caveats.  Let's start with the good: even older, this game's design from a visual standpoint still holds up.  The levels are varied with some interesting twists, the enemies are mostly the same design but still look good, bosses are simple, but still look good.  The aesthetic still holds up well and does something different than the usual post-apocalyptic thing (closest I've seen recently would be trailers for Horizon: Zero Dawn).  The voice acting is superb, especially between the two primary characters.  The combat feels good - impact feels nice and heavy, and while there isn't a lot of depth, it still feels satisfactory.  Bonus, my steam controller worked immediately with only tweaking needed, so I was happy with that.On the downside, the camera SUCKS.  Easily the worst camera on a third person game that I've played in a long, long time.  You'll die from things off screen, you'll get hit in combat from not being able to move the camera fast enough to see the enemies - it is REALLY frustrating.  Thankfully, the in-game checkpoints are plentiful, so there's never more than a couple minutes to move through again.  The other gripe I have is that the story is phenomenal, but it doesn't really end - there's no setup for a sequel; the story just kind of ends without any real feeling of finality or closure.  It doesn't take away from the rest of the journey, so to speak - but it does kind of sour some satisfaction with it.Still, worth five bucks on sale.  If you're looking for an adventure beat'em up, it's not bad at all.  Also good for people getting used to a Steam Controller.

Posted: January 14
												I didn't expect to like this game as much as I did. Obviously I expected to like it, or I wouldn't have bought it, but while I expected "okay", I got "pretty great actually".I've completed the main story at time of writing, but there are still extra things to do so I'll still be playing for a few more days. Maybe even a second run to complete achievements. The main story is about twenty hours long (on hard) if you don't make too many mistakes, and it's pretty damn linear."Linear" never used to be my thing, but Enslaved does it well. It has a story to tell and it tells it, and in my opinion the cutscenes, voice acting, and general characterisation are great. They really brought the game up from "worth playing" to "you should play this". Be warned, though, if you're looking for a faithful retelling of Monkey's Journey to the West, you will be sorely disappointed. This is the definition of loose adaptation. If you know the original story, you will see clever little references, but if you don't this is not the way to learn it. This is, in fact, a completely original story that happens to contain elements from Journey to the West.I recommend playing with a controller. I don't often say this, because in 90% of cases KB+M is always going to be better, but this is definitely one of those remaining 10%. Platforming and combat are incredibly awkward, but not downright impossible, without a joystick of some kind.And, yes, the other reviews are right. This is a bad port. Fortunately, most of the major issues can be fixed by tweaking inis, and there are plenty of guides right here on steam on how to do that.Much more fun than expected. Marginally more feels than expected.EDIT: Pigsy's Perfect 10 is surprisingly challenging, and I love his "crouch".

Posted: February 18
												I'm gonna go with a YEAH - OH HELL YEAH - on this one.As a guy who was spoon-fed the old-school cartoon version of The Monkey King as a child, (the one that was too ugly to be called anime,) I was somewhat skeptical on this reboot. And, though I will grant that the whole post-apocalypse-robots-wasteland-deal took a while to grow on me, I must confess, in the end: The story, (it took forever after the opening Action Sequence too get REALLY interesting,) quite simply DRAGS you into it, (kicking and screaming if it has to,) and if you have ANY knowledge of the original story I mentioned earlier, you can't help but contemplate the complexity of the concept, once you've finished the game. (noooooo WAKE UP... Not Even One spoiler! - Once you've finished the game y'all might even get that joke.)Right, so... The game itself - (I'll leave the story with you for evaluation.) The controls are actually so easy you have to make an effort to get it wrong, (granted it'll take you a while to learn to trust that fact.) Other games could learn something from these Devs. I'm not saying this platform of control or key configuration is the best ever, cause it's not. It's just that the controls are SO responsive that you actually have to be CAREFUL not to jump the gun. (You'll understand soon enough. Half of the game IS a 3D-Platformer, after all...)The Graphics are utterly beautiful, spectacular and fantastic. (Granted, there are a few "gaps," where you go WTF because the beauty goes right out the window. But it's not that big a deal. The Game never really loses touch with it's background scene, so it works even without the sparkles on it.)The extras are... - extra. I don't really know how else to put it. You don't really need it. You don't really need to go through the game again with a new "mod" turned on, but if you wanna replay, and re-experience the stunning story with a completely "weird" or "ridiculous" outfit or other mods, you can. I personally didn't. (But then, I spent a good long week, after completing the game, reasoning out all the story-lines shout-outs to the Original Story; the philosophy; the multitude of morals implied in the game; and how absurdly many White Rabbits there are sprinkled around the entire storyline.)Combat System: Oh for the love of pete... - I know I said the controls are fabulous, (cause they are, repsonse-wise) but the combat/shooting system is REALLY flawed. Multi-target tracking is TOO DAMNED SLOW. (You'll get why later on in the game, when multiple enemies begin to become a stable fixture.)Puzzles - Well, they're not Mensa-Crackers but they WILL annoy you, if nothing else, because they take time to complete. - (You WILL be happy once you're finished with one, and curse the Devs whenever you find the next one...) But that's the way with puzzles in a 3D platform game, isn't it?Funfactor... - Meh...! It's fun the first time. But It's kind of an adrenaline-based thing. Run over here. Move this. Up, down, right, bla bla bla. Kill this, hack that, hurry, move this way - OOPS blocked, find another way. All the while, usually with a "hurry or your companion will die!" kind of thing hanging over you. It works, once. I found it hard to engage properly during the second playthrough, but I'm thinking it was just too soon. I've since left the game on the shelf a while to age a bit. I'm thinking when I dust it off again and play it once more, it'll be fun again.So Overall?Pros 7/10 - Good Game; Great Story;  Interesting Characters (they actually grow with the story! thumbs up for the writers!)  ; Great Graphics, SOOOO MUCH Better Than Average Controls, everythings explained, everythings understandable and generally doable, (just mind your timing,) ; the multiphasing platforming (and that's as far as I'll go towards spoilers,) works very well, even if it's a little confusing at first; Great, Scenic, Rich 3D Environments for a Platformer! - I DO hope that other Devs are taking notes. Depth Matters!Cons 3/10 - The Combat/Shooting System (see above) is without a doubt the most frustrating problem in the entire game. I died more times during "that" phase than I did in the rest of the entire game; Replayabillity; I love your game, Devs and I love your effort, but it's a little heavy to pick up a second time in short order, when you know the score and how it all plays out - (F-Y-I, a couple of mods won't change that. I WILL play again, but it won't be because of the mods.) ; Finally - Not enough FUN-Factor. The game, while certainly a great re-boot of the Monkey King lore, a great take on the 3D-multi-Platformer, a gorgeous piece of art, graphics-wise - it's all good, really - but there's a lack of good clean fun. (Oh I DID laugh quite a bit during the development of the story and the characters, but it was all soooo serious. I get it, I do, The Monkey King was big on High Drama. But it was funny too. So if you're gonna revamp it, why not do the funny as well? I'm not asking for Crash Bandicoot fall on your bum Fun, or witty one-two-or-three-liners. Just give us a reason to like PLAYING the game, besides getting it out the way so we can get to the next cut-scene?)So... - Good game. Very Pretty. Great Story. Fun, but not tons of it. I'd reccomend it to Story-Lovers, whether they know or like The Monkey King saga, or not. Oh yeah, and just so you know, (I like this, but I'm guessing some people don't,) from a gamer's point of view, this game is LOOOOOOOONG! So bring patience, lean back, and enjoy.

Posted: March 2
												This game may not be well known or be a great one, but it's still a pretty good game. ENSLAVED is a bit generic action adventure game, with some platforming which is almost always on auto-pilot. The combat is fluid, but a bit simplistic, without complex combos and with only a few extra gadgets. But honestly, this game doesn't need those. The game focuses on it's story and characters, and while the story isn't that great (but good), the characters, the voice acting and their interactions are really well done. The game lasts around 10 hours, which is normal for this genre. The graphics and music are also good. There's also a DLC mini-story, that although has a different style of gameplay, i also enjoyed it, slightly less that the main game. I recommend this game on sale.
